docs.snippet: Karl Rove, President Bush's chief political adviser, sought today to turn the war into partisan advantage, telling Republicans gathered here that the administration's handling of terrorism could be an important theme for the party to trumpet in th...
docs.lead_paragraph: Karl Rove, President Bush's chief political adviser, sought today to turn the war into partisan advantage, telling Republicans gathered here that the administration's handling of terrorism could be an important theme for the party to trumpet in the November midterm elections. ''Americans trust the Republicans to do a better job of keeping our communities and our families safe,'' Mr. Rove said in a luncheon speech at the winter meeting of the Republican National Committee. ''We can also go to the country on this issue because they trust the Republican Party to do a better job of protecting and strengthening America's military might and thereby protecting America.''
docs.abstract: Karl Rove, Pres Bush's chief political aide, holds Bush's handling of terrorism should be key theme for party to tout in Nov midterm elections, Republican National Committee meeting, Austin, Tex; speaks after party elects Marc Racicot chairman; Racicot dismisses criticism of arrangement in which he will continue to work for Bracewell & Patterson law firm, but stop lobbying for it, interview; Democrats score Rove for politicizing war (M)

headline.main: Bush Adviser Suggests War as Campaign Theme

docs.snippet: Zameer Pasha, a 42-year-old Muslim, owns a small store in the heart of a Muslim neighborhood here. The store, Pan Plaza, sells American brands of soft drinks, ice cream and cigarettes, along with some locally made products, like cookies and chewin...
docs.lead_paragraph: Zameer Pasha, a 42-year-old Muslim, owns a small store in the heart of a Muslim neighborhood here. The store, Pan Plaza, sells American brands of soft drinks, ice cream and cigarettes, along with some locally made products, like cookies and chewing tobacco. It is thousands of miles away from Kabul, and Mr. Pasha has no known relatives in Afghanistan.
docs.abstract: Muslims in India are once again buying American products now that Taliban regime in Afghanistan has fallen; Muslim leaders in India called for boycott of American products after aerial strikes on Afghanistan began in October; Zameer Pasha, owner of store in Bangalore, India, comments; photo (M)

headline.main: Long Reach of War in Afghanistan

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The United States is on slippery ground in asserting that the Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters detained at Guantánamo Bay are ''unlawful combatants'' and not prisoners of war (news article, Jan. 12). Article 5 of the third Geneva C...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The United States is on slippery ground in asserting that the Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters detained at Guantánamo Bay are ''unlawful combatants'' and not prisoners of war (news article, Jan. 12). Article 5 of the third Geneva Convention requires that if there is any doubt regarding the status of captured combatants, they must be treated as prisoners of war until a ''competent tribunal'' determines their status. Taliban fighters as part of the Taliban army are most likely prisoners of war. Al Qaeda fighters, to the extent they wore a distinctive sign like a black headband or took up arms to resist invaders and carried arms openly, are also prisoners of war.
docs.abstract: Letter by Michael Ratner of Center for Constitutional Rights says US is on 'slippery ground' in asserting that Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters detained at Guantanamo Bay are 'unlawful combatants' and not prisoners of war (S)

headline.main: When Are Captives Prisoners of War?

docs.snippet: THIS is the story of a pair of 18th-century saddle pistols that were owned by three heroes of the American Revolution -- the Marquis de Lafayette, George Washington and Andrew Jackson -- and the friendships that developed among these men.    The p...
docs.lead_paragraph: THIS is the story of a pair of 18th-century saddle pistols that were owned by three heroes of the American Revolution -- the Marquis de Lafayette, George Washington and Andrew Jackson -- and the friendships that developed among these men. The pistols were worn into battle in America by Lafayette, who gave them to Washington as reminders of the two men's passionate commitment to fight to the death for liberty. Jackson, to whom the pistols were bequeathed years later, shared that commitment, and marked it by passing them back to the Lafayette family, where they remained for a century, gaining, in the words written and spoken about them and their owners, the intellectual patina of mementos.
docs.abstract: Article traces history of pair of 18th-century saddle pistols, worn into battle in America by Marquis de Lafayette, who gave them to George Washington as reminders of their commitment to liberty; Washington bequeathed them to Andrew Jackson, who passed them back to Lafayette family; Christie's, which plans sale in mid-January, estimates that pistols will bring more than $1.5 million; photo (M)

headline.main: Silent Witnesses to War and Fellowship

docs.snippet: A leading voice for Kashmiri independence has been brutally beaten by Indian authorities during his latest incarceration, supporters said. Yasin Malik, chairman of the Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front, was arrested on March 25 after the seizure ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A leading voice for Kashmiri independence has been brutally beaten by Indian authorities during his latest incarceration, supporters said. Yasin Malik, chairman of the Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front, was arrested on March 25 after the seizure of $100,000 from a couple who are said to have confessed to smuggling the money into Kashmir on Mr. Malik's behalf. Barry Bearak (NYT)
docs.abstract: Backers of Kashmiri independence leader Yasin Malik, jailed after seizure of $100,000 from couple who confessed to smuggling money into Kashmir on his behalf, say he was brutally beaten by Indian authorities (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: India: Accusations Of Brutality

docs.snippet: Talks on the future of the country will resume today, a week after the government withdrew because of a rebel attack in eastern Congo, said Ketumile Masire, the facilitator of the inter-Congolese dialogue. The negotiations, in South Africa, are ex...
docs.lead_paragraph: Talks on the future of the country will resume today, a week after the government withdrew because of a rebel attack in eastern Congo, said Ketumile Masire, the facilitator of the inter-Congolese dialogue. The negotiations, in South Africa, are expected to go on until mid-April and produce a transition government. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)
docs.abstract: Talks on future of Congo will resume in South Africa following interruption caused by rebel attacks; negotiations are expected to produce transition government (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Talks To Resume

docs.snippet: THIS much we know for certain. Ezra Chamberlin of Killingly was killed in action in South Carolina during the Civil War.     But on which side? Was he a Union Army private killed in the Battle of Fort Wagner in 1863 or a Confederate sailor who die...
docs.lead_paragraph: THIS much we know for certain. Ezra Chamberlin of Killingly was killed in action in South Carolina during the Civil War. But on which side? Was he a Union Army private killed in the Battle of Fort Wagner in 1863 or a Confederate sailor who died aboard the submarine H. L. Hunley when it sank off Charleston in 1864?
docs.abstract: Article on mystery surrounding Ezra Chamberlin of Killingly, Conn, whose medallion was found near skeletal remains of crew member aboard submarine H L Hunley, which sank off Charleston in 1864 and was raised from bottom of harbor in 2000; Chamberlin was thought to be member of Union Army killed in battle of Fort Wagner in 1863 and buried in family plot but may have been turncoat who died aboard submarine; photos (M)

headline.main: A Connecticut Yankee? Or a Turncoat?

docs.snippet: With Mauritius, Macedonia and Cyprus acting this week, 55 of the required 60 nations have ratified the treaty creating the International Criminal Court, which would be the first permanent tribunal set up to try individuals charged with genocide, w...
docs.lead_paragraph: With Mauritius, Macedonia and Cyprus acting this week, 55 of the required 60 nations have ratified the treaty creating the International Criminal Court, which would be the first permanent tribunal set up to try individuals charged with genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity. Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations said he expected the court to be established by July. The Bush administration opposes it. Barbara Crossette (NYT)
docs.abstract: Treaty creating International Criminal Court has been ratified by 55 of required 60 nations; Secretary Gen Kofi Annan says he expects court to be established by July; Bush administration opposes it (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | World: Criminal Court Nears Reality

docs.snippet: Art History    Now 70, Ganjiro Nakamura III has been a living national treasure of Japan by governmental declaration since 1994. One of the foremost Kabuki actors, he is an onnagata, or female impersonator, continuing a tradition begun when the er...
docs.lead_paragraph: Art History Now 70, Ganjiro Nakamura III has been a living national treasure of Japan by governmental declaration since 1994. One of the foremost Kabuki actors, he is an onnagata, or female impersonator, continuing a tradition begun when the erotic overtones of Kabuki impelled 17th-century authorities to bar women and then boys from the stage. At 8 tonight at the Japan Society, he will perform the dance classic ''Fuji Musume'' (''The Wisteria Maiden''). Set in the early 19th century, this dance expresses both a woman's constancy in the face of her lover's deceit and the Japanese view of the intimacy between people and nature.
docs.abstract: Foremost Japanese Kabuki actor Ganjiro Nakamura 3rd, 70, will perform at Japan Society; Rendez-Vous With French Cinema 2002 is set to open at Lincoln Center's Walter Reade Theater; fourth annual BAMkids Film Festival will open at Brooklyn Academy of Music; exhibit of 75 objects from permanent collection of battle objects and pictures will open at Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena, Calif; composer Cy Coleman is preparing for his first club engagement in years at Joe's Pub in Manhattan; Ghazal Ensemble will perform in benefit for World Music Institute at New York Society for Ethical Culture; photos (M)

docs.snippet: Two chain-smoking teenage twins who led a rebel group called God's Army in Myanmar, the former Burma, have been transferred from a Thai police compound to a refugee camp for ethnic Karen refugees. Johnny and Luther Htoo, who are now about 13 years...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two chain-smoking teenage twins who led a rebel group called God's Army in Myanmar, the former Burma, have been transferred from a Thai police compound to a refugee camp for ethnic Karen refugees. Johnny and Luther Htoo, who are now about 13 years old, surrendered to Thai authorities a year ago and have been waiting for months for immigrant visas to the United States. But they have also told reporters that they prefer not to go. Seth Mydans (NYT)
docs.abstract: Johnny and Luther Htoo, 13, twins who led rebel group called God's Army in Myanmar, are transferred from Thai police compound to refugee camp for ethnic Karen refugees; photo (S)
